title: Green or Greenwashing?

authors.name: Rémi Césaro
authors.title: Resource Efficiency Consultant, Director of Zero Waste City

summary: This article explains green terminology, how to identify greenwashing, and provides guidance on selecting genuinely green products and services while understanding regulatory guidelines in Singapore.

key_concepts.definition: Products, services or practices that claim reduced, minimal or no harm for the environment. Note that none of these words are defined by national or international standards.

aspects: Manufactured from toxic-free, renewable, or sustainable ingredients
Can be recyclable, compostable, or reusable
Packaging can be recyclable, compostable, or reusable
Has reduced or zero carbon footprint
Has reduced or zero plastic footprint

practices: Reduce air emissions (SOx, NOx, fine particulate matter, etc.)
Use sustainable raw materials (e.g.: renewable, recycled)

key_concepts.definition: The misuse of terms like 'eco-friendly', 'green', 'sustainable' in corporate communications promulgating an image of environmental responsibility, which in fact is unfounded or intentionally misleading.

ten_signs_of_greenwashing.description: Words or terms with no clear meaning (e.g. 'eco-friendly')
Such as efficient lightbulbs made in a factory that pollutes rivers
Green images that indicate a (unjustified) green impact (e.g. flowers blooming from exhaust pipes)
Emphasising one tiny green attribute when everything else is not green
Declaring you are slightly greener than the rest, even if the rest are pretty terrible
Eco friendly cigarettes, anyone? Greening a dangerous product does not make it safe
Information that only a scientist could check or understand
A label that looks like third party endorsement—except that it is made up
It could be right, but where is the evidence?

singapore_regulations: Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS)

related_terms.definition: To tout a business or organization's commitment to social responsibilities and to use this perception for public relations and economic gain
Businesses and organisations that opt to stay quiet about their climate strategies because they fear being called out for greenwashing
The practice of giving environmentally friendly names to groups whose agendas have little to do with the welfare of the environment
The use of support for LGBT rights and issues by a state or business to boost its own image
